summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the US v. Maxwell case, discussing significant technical deficiencies in the discovery production of photographic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residence. The defense raises issues with corrupt files, mismatched metadata, and inability to properly review thousands of images.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell, raising multiple discovery deficiencies regarding photo evidence from Epstein's residence.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on discovery deficiency correspondence.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on discovery deficiency correspondence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in US v. Maxwell case, unable to review discovery files at MDC due to technical issues.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the owner of the residence where CDs containing photographic evidence were seized.

connections.description: Menninger is defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case.
Pagliuca is defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case.
Sternheim is defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case.
Maxwell is charged in connection with Epstein's activities; evidence seized from Epstein's residence is central to her case.

events.title: Discovery Deficiency Conference Call
events.description: Email scheduling an 11am call to discuss photo and discovery deficiencies in the Maxwell case.

events.title: SDNY_PROD011 Production
events.description: Production of images from CDs seized from Epstein's residence provided to defense.

locations: Southern District of New York, St. Plaza, New York, NY 10007
New York Office (FBI Child Exploitation and Human Trafficking Task Force)
keyFacts: Defense attorneys identified significant technical problems with discovery production, including corrupt Excel spreadsheets and thousands of unreadable photo files.
There were discrepancies between metadata indexes and actual files, with 65 production numbers not matching the index and 17 files having no hash values.
The government produced 40,567 files from CDs seized from Epstein's residence, but the defense could not properly match metadata to the native files.
Defense argued their client's constitutional right to review discovery was being impeded by technical deficiencies and proposed raising the issue with the Court.
The defense questioned the 'highly confidential' designation of nude/partially-nude photos, noting they didn't see evidence of child pornography in what they could view.
